body:
Okay, so, the principle I was following: proposing a backend that will simply change the low-level subroutines such that they become differentiable or accelerated for GPUs. Doing a differentiable which will be fast for GPU is also feasible though it might require a bit of time. Thus, since the back-end thing seems to be a bit off today lines, I propose to follow an alternative strategy.

I believe it is ok to integrate it currently as a marginal file... any thoughts?

to make sure I understood correctly: the default scattering is faster (on gpu) but the other is differentiable, so for now we need to keep both?

I still think even in this case we need a much cleaner way this presents to the user. The current version seems really unintuitive to me and I imagine many people won't realize this functionality even exists or how to use it. I especially dont like the user needs to figure out to load a different version of the scattering from another file somewhere.

At a minimum I would say the Scattering2d object should be the sole one that can access this file (calling the alternative scattering when the user specifies it in constructor arguments). 

More cleanly I think would be to integrate the code for modulus, periodize, cdgmm, etc and simply have the Scattering init object select which ones will be used later

@eickenberg  thoughts?

> to make sure I understood correctly: the default scattering is faster (on gpu) but the other is differentiable, so for now we need to keep both?

Yes. If you check the code, you will see diff.py is a hint to avoid using cuda kernels such that every operation is differentiable.

> I still think even in this case we need a much cleaner way this presents to the user. The current version seems really unintuitive to me and I imagine many people won't realize this functionality even exists or how to use it. I especially dont like the user needs to figure out to load a different version of the scattering from another file somewhere.

I agree with this. A flag?

> At a minimum I would say the Scattering2d object should be the one that access this file (calling the alternative scattering when the user specifies it in constructor arguments).
> 
> More cleanly I think would be to integrate the code for modulus, periodize, cdgmm, etc and simply have the Scattering init object select which ones will be used later

That's the backend style of coding I had in mind.. not sure how to incorporate it/if it makes sens now

> @eickenberg thoughts?

> > to make sure I understood correctly: the default scattering is faster (on gpu) but the other is differentiable, so for now we need to keep both?
> 
> Yes. If you check the code, you will see diff.py is a hint to avoid using cuda kernels such that every operation is differentiable.
> 
> > I still think even in this case we need a much cleaner way this presents to the user. The current version seems really unintuitive to me and I imagine many people won't realize this functionality even exists or how to use it. I especially dont like the user needs to figure out to load a different version of the scattering from another file somewhere.
> 
> I agree with this. A flag?
> 
> > At a minimum I would say the Scattering2d object should be the one that access this file (calling the alternative scattering when the user specifies it in constructor arguments).

This first suggestion is not the same as the "backend" which I understand might take a bit of time to test if we had to implement it now. I am saying at a minium we can have Scattering be accessible through only the Scattering2d object. So for example the user would only import from one file

`import Scattering2d as Scattering 

Scattering(28,28,3) #to use the fast scattering
Scattering(28,28,3,differentiable=True) #to use the differentiable version`

> > More cleanly I think would be to integrate the code for modulus, periodize, cdgmm, etc and simply have the Scattering init object select which ones will be used later
> 
> That's the backend style of coding I had in mind.. not sure how to incorporate it/if it makes sens now

I guess this would be slightly trickier than the option above but I still dont see why its so complex. The modulus,periodize,cdgmm funcitons you define in differentiably.py are already defined inside utils.py when the user calls jit=False for their initializer. So the only thing to do would be to build a unified interface for the fft calls isnt that right? Cant it be done the same way (jit=False) would trigger a diff behavior in __call__ 

> 
> > @eickenberg thoughts?

>  So the only thing to do would be to build a unified interface

Yeah. This is the issue actually

I agree with the ideas.

My thoughts are:

This is out of the scope of the current release for lack of person power to get this implemented correctly (correct me if I'm wrong) (by *implemented* I mean: implementation, full test coverage, docstrings, and documentation). So it should be entirely removed from the current code base.

The way this can be added back is by
1. Refactoring the code so it has the same interface as the 2d scattering code
2. Benchmarking it against the non-differentiable scattering code and
a) if there is a tradeoff, then keep both while indicating the tradeoff in the docs
b) if the differentiable has similar speed, remove the non-differentiable (unless this removal blocks backend switching).

I would second the fact to remove it if it cannot be fixed, the presence of fft.py and differentiable.py do make the code base much less readable esp since 95% of the code inside them is already in other files. 

It would be a shame though since many ppl are interested in the differentiable functionality.

I still find it a bit hard to understand why its so complex to integrate it in a simple way, the "backend" functionality is already implemented (periodize,modulus,cdgmm all have defaults to simple pytorch versions...identical to those reimplemented in differentiable.py). Differentiable.py only differs in the scattering code at calls to these functions and to fft callse. The code that powers the fft as far as I can tell is identical save some formatting to the one found in utils.py. The only issue edouard has pointed out is that for the fast scattering version (non-differentiable) he wants to avoid having an autograd variable, but this seems like it can be fixed easily with an if statement (that maybe is slightly nasty depending who you ask)
e.g. on this line
https://github.com/eickenberg/scattering_transform/blob/master/scattering/scattering2d/FFT.py#L114

something like this should be able to avoid using autograd in the case of the core fast scattering implementation.

```def fft_c2c(input,jit=True):
    if jit: 
        return FFT_C2C()(input) # with autograd
    else: 
        return fft.c2c(input) #cufft directly```

> I still find it a bit hard to understand why its so complex to integrate it in a simple way, the "backend" functionality is already implemented (periodize,modulus,cdgmm all have defaults to simple pytorch versions

I don't think it is hard. 

It just needs to be properly thought through (i.e. when is the backend loaded, can it be switched after import, how is it represented -- there are many extremely ugly and unsustainable ways of doing this and few good ones. `keras` is a relatively clean example of how it could be done).

After being thought through it needs to be fully implemented. This takes time, usually more than expected. So we would need somebody dedicated to making this happen.

Well we are talking about highly useful additional functionality not there that happens to reuses 95% of the same code (just adding an autograd variable via an if statement done somewhere internally). Just picking the backend when instantiating the Scattering variable seems reasonable to me.

> Just picking the backend when instantiating the Scattering variable seems reasonable to me

this will be easy as long as both versions are pytorch. As soon as they are not (remember the cupy backend idea), then the main files must never import anything from either torch or cupy and must run on one backend without the other even being installed. This is currently not possible.

Right, but currently Mathieu for example uses Variable everywhere ... I think the long term goal to make it pytorch independent shouldnt prevent us from releasing a highly requested ( but not totally nasty as now) version of differentiable for  2d.

OK, so let's add in this 2d differentiable functionality for this release then.

@eugenium can you try doing this? (assuming it costs you not too much time, since you seem to currently be the most acutely informed person concerning this part of the codebase)

---

This leads to the immediate future milestones of:
1. differentiability for 1D and 3D (that should be as quick as adding the `backward` op in their respective FFT implementations)
2. unifying the FFT codes to make maintaining it easier (and maybe to put pytorch-fft out of business because they don't store plans)
3. separating out backends (making it possible to add in cupy, and maybe tf2 if it's not as nasty as previous versions, and hedge against pytorch tanking because they made too many changes in 0.4 -> 1.0 :) )

I'll add these as issues and tag them appropriately

> OK, so let's add in this 2d differentiable functionality for this release then.
> 
> @eugenium can you try doing this? (assuming it costs you not too much time, since you seem to currently be the most acutely informed person concerning this part of the codebase)
> 
> This leads to the immediate future milestones of:
> 
> 1. differentiability for 1D and 3D (that should be as quick as adding the `backward` op in their respective FFT implementations)

I think the 1D code of Mathieu is already differentiable

> 2. unifying the FFT codes to make maintaining it easier (and maybe to put pytorch-fft out of business because they don't store plans)
> 3. separating out backends (making it possible to add in cupy, and maybe tf2 if it's not as nasty as previous versions, and hedge against pytorch tanking because they made too many changes in 0.4 -> 1.0 :) )
> 
> I'll add these as issues and tag them appropriately

> I think the 1D code of Mathieu is already differentiable

yes, at least according to this line: https://github.com/eickenberg/scattering_transform/blob/master/scattering/scattering1d/fft_wrapper.py#L280

3d looks like it isn't.
